name: ðŸ†•  - Arduino Sketch for sending light sensor data to Sigfox
info:
- Source code for the Arduino sketch:
  
https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino

- The code here is very similar to Practical 2,
  except that the Sigfox parts have been
  filled in.

- This Arduino sketch reads the sensor data 
  from the Grove light sensor and sends the data
  to the Sigfox network. 

- The sensor value is read every 10 seconds.

- When we write Arduino code, normally we don't
  write from scratch. We use the code that's
  provided by the maker of the sensor or
  communications module (Bluetooth, WiFi, Sigfox etc)
 
- The Arduino code here was derived from the 
  official sensor specifications and sample code:

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove-Light_Sensor/

https://github.com/Seeed-Studio/Light_Sensor/blob/master/examples/Light_Sensor/Light_Sensor.ino 

- Check the above links and compare the
  similarity of the code

- We will likely be using various Grove sensors 
  for our project because they are easy to connect.
  Here is the list of Grove sensors available,
  please choose sensors that are compatible with Arduino:

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove_System/

- SeeedStudio provides sample Arduino code for Grove Sensors on wiki.seeed.cc, e.g.

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove-Sound_Sensor/ 

- Every Arduino Sketch has 3 sections: **Declarations, Setup, Loop**. Click the nodes to learn more.

name: Setup
info:
- Click here
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L25-L39

- Every Arduino program has a **Setup** function
  that is run once upon startup.

- We use this section to initialise the sensor

- When using a Sigfox shield with Arduino, we
  normally initialise the Sigfox module in the `setup()` function.
  Some Sigfox modules include a Power Amplifier
  and may need some time to power up.

name: Loop
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L69-L117

- Every Arduino sketch has a **Loop** function
  that is run repeatedly after **Setup.**  

- Here we read the sensor value from the Arduino
  light sensor and display it

- The light sensor should be connected to 
  **Port A0** of the Grove Shield.  This is
  an **Analog Port,** since the light sensor
  is an analog sensor.

- The sensor value is read every 10 seconds.

-  When running with a real Sigfox shield,
   we should insert a delay of 10 seconds 
   at the end of the `loop()` function.
   We should not send more than 1 message
   within 10 seconds.

name: General Setup
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L42-L49

- We declare the **Setup** function as `void setup()`.
  This means it accepts no parameters and 
  returns no values.  In C++, functions start
  with `{` and end with `}`.

- When we use the **Serial Monitor** we are
  actually connecting through our computer's
  COM serial port to the USB interface to
  another serial port located on the Arduino board.
  The Arduino's serial port is also known as 
  **UART - Universal Asynchronous Receiver / Transmitter**

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_asynchronous_receiver/transmitter

- In most Arduino sketches we use the serial
  port to display debug messages. That's why
  the serial port is connected to the
  Serial Monitor

- By convention, we use 9,600 bits per second
  to connect to the serial port.  This is set
  through `Serial.begin(9600)`

- We use `Serial.println` to output messages
  to the serial port / Serial Monitor.
  This section will print `Running setup...`
  when the sketch starts running.

- Why did we call function `F(...)`? Because
  RAM is severely limited. By calling `F(...)`
  we store the `Running setup...` string
  in **Flash Memory** instead of RAM, 
  so we have more usable memory.  

- When you compile a sketch you may see:

```
Sketch uses 19,168 bytes (59%) of program storage space. Maximum is 32,256 bytes.
Global variables use 1,376 bytes (67%) of dynamic memory, leaving 672 bytes for local variables. Maximum is 2,048 bytes.
```

- That means the Arduino Uno has only **2KB of usuable RAM**.
  The sketch occupies 19KB of Flash Memory, which is a lot bigger
  than available RAM.

name: Sensor Setup
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L51-L57

- There is no sensor setup needed for the Grove Light Sensor.

- Some smart sensors (e.g. air pressure sensor)
  may need some time to start up and warm up.

name: ðŸ†•  - Sigfox Module Setup
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L59-L66

- The code here initialises the Sigfox
  module before transmitting Sigfox messages

- `transceiver.begin()` calls the `begin()`
  function in the `UnaShieldV1` class.
  This function powers up the Sigfox module
  and checks whether it's operational.

- The `begin()` function returns false if the module
  is not operational.  Hence we check whether
  the return value is false.

- The `!` operator in C++ is the `not` operator,
  it changes true to false and vice versa.
  So when `transceiver.begin()` returns false,
  `!transceiver.begin()` will return true.

- Hence when `!transceiver.begin()` is true,
  the module must have failed.  The program
  stops with a message `Unable to init SIGFOX module...`

- In the C++ convention, all conditions in the
  `if` statement must be enclosed by brackets:

  `if (condition) statement`

name: Sensor Loop
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L70-L78

- In this section we read the sensor data.

- `int light_level` declares an Integer variable
  named `light_level` which we will use
  to save the sensor value

- `light_level = analogRead(LIGHT_SENSOR)` reads
  the value of Analog Port 0, i.e. A0.
  We declared `LIGHT_SENSOR` to be `A0`
  in the **General Declarations** section

- All C++ statements must end with `;`

- Then we print the `light_level` to the
  serial port / Serial Monitor

- Why didn't we call `F(...)` for `light_level`?
  Because `light_level` is a variable and
  can't be stored in Flash Memory, which is
  read-only. `F(...)` should be called for
  text strings that never change.

name: ðŸ†•  - Sigfox Module Loop
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L80-L112

- This section contains 5 parts of code for
  sending sensor data via Sigfox:

  1. Declaring the counter variables
  2. Reading the temperature of the Sigfox module
  3. Composing a sensor data message
  4. Sending the message
  5. Showing the sending status

name: Loop Delay
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L114-L116

- Remember that we are not supposed to send
  2 Sigfox messages within 10 seconds.  In fact
  the guideline is that we should only send
  maximum 140 messages in a day.

- Also we shouldn't read sensors too often. This drains
  the battery faster.

- By calling `delay(10000)` we introduce a
  10-second delay into the loop.  We specify
  10,000 because the unit is milliseconds,
  so 10 seconds = 10000 milliseconds

- So the program pauses here for 10 seconds
  before running `loop()` again

- Unlike normal computers, a microcontroller
  like Arduino doesn't know how to end / exit / quit!
  It will happily run `loop()` forever
  until you disconnect the power.

name: Declarations
info:
- Click to see the section: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L1-L39

- All Arduino programs have a **Declarations** section
  at the beginning to declare any required
  library functions or global constants / variables

- An Arduino Sketch is a C++ program, so we
  use `//` and `/* ... */` to denote comments

name: Sensor Declarations
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L11-L23

- Here we declare any library functions, constants
  and variables used by the sensor

- The Grove Light Sensor uses the standard
  Analog port and doesn't require any libraries

- The `#ifdef ... #endif` is a C++ Preprocessor
  Directive. During the C++ compilation, the
  C++ compiler checks whether we are compiling
  for the Bean Arduino Device, and if so
  use port A2 instead of the default A0 for
  connecting to the light sensor.  We are
  using the Arduino Uno, so `LIGHT_SENSOR`
  will be set to `A0`.

name: ðŸ†•  - Sigfox Module Declarations
info:
- Click here:
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L25-L39

- This section declares the library functions, constants
  and variables needed for the Sigfox transmission

- `#include "SIGFOX.h"` is the standard way
  to tell the Arduino IDE that we will be
  using the Sigfox library.

- Technically, this command will cause the
  Arduino compiler to compile the contents
  of the file `SIGFOX.h` defined in the Sigfox
  library.  The file `SIGFOX.h` declares
  the classes (e.g. `UnaShieldV1`) that 
  may be called to execute the Sigfox
  functions.

- `device` is not used and may be ignored.
  All messages sent by the Sigfox module will
  automatically include the Sigfox Device ID.
  This Device ID is integral to Sigfox security
  and may not be altered.

- `useEmulator` is set to false because some
  Sigfox modules allow an emulation mode
  that enables the module to transmit
  data locally to a Sigfox emulation basestation,
  for testing purposes.

- `echo` is set to true so that the library
  will display debug messages to the Serial Monitor.

- `country` should be set to `Country_SG` for
  Singapore.  Sigfox devices operate in different
  frequencies for 4 zones, this configures the
  library to use Zone 4 for Singapore.

  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/wiki/UnaShield

  **Zone 1 (RCZ1):** Europe, South Africa

  **Zone 2 (RCZ2):** North America

  **Zone 3 (RCZ3):** Japan

  **Zone 4 (RCZ4):** Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore, New Zealand, South America, Taiwan

- `transceiver` is the Arduino object that
  we will use to transmit data.  This is the
  main object exposed by the Sigfox library
  to allow data transmission.

- The Sigfox library supports 2 types of
  Sigfox modules: Radiocrafts (`UnaShieldV1`)
  and Wisol (`UnaShieldV2S`).  We shall be using
  the Radiocrafts module and `UnaShieldV1` library.

- For advanced Arduino programmers: `UnaShieldV1` is
  actually an alias for the `Radiocrafts` class
  (using a `#define` preprocessor directive).
  The Sigfox library code may be found here:

  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/Radiocrafts.cpp

name: General Declarations
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L1-L9

- This is a comment (marked by `//`) that describes the program
  features. 

- The connections for the Arduino Pins is
  described in Exercise 1

name: ðŸ†•  - Declarations
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L83-L85

- Here we declare `counter` as the total number
  of messages sent

- `successCount` is the actual number of messages
  sent successfully, i.e. the module didn't
  return any errors

- `failCount` is the number of messages that
  returned an error code during sending

- Note that the device won't know the actual number
  of messages delivered to the Sigfox cloud
  because the transmission is based on 
  broadcast without acknowledgement.

- Compared with WiFi and 4G, this method of
  transmission by Sigfox greatly simplifies the
  device processing needed to send sensor data,
  and prolongs the battery life of the device.

- It also enables the device to sleep for long
  periods of time, because it's not expecting
  to receive any return data.

name: ðŸ†•  - Read Sigfox Module temperature
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L87-L88

- The Sigfox module includes a built-in
  Temperature Sensor that senses its internal
  temperature.

- Some modules may overheat when we transmit
  data too frequently.  This sensor is
  meant for us to detect this condition.

- This is the temperature of the module, not
  the ambient surroundings. So it can't be used
  to measure the ambient temperature.

- Calling `transceiver.getTemperature(temperature)`
  will read the internal temperature sensor and
  set the `temperature` variable

name: ðŸ†•  - Compose structured sensor data message
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L90-L95

- What's a "structured sensor data message"?
  It's possible to send sensor data any way we
  want in 12 bytes, the maximum message length
  for Sigfox.

- However we prefer a standard way of sending
  sensor data whether it's text, integer or
  floating point (decimal).  The `Message` class
  in the Sigfox library allows this.

- We also prefer to send the sensor field names.
  So when the IoT Gateway (e.g. AWS IoT) receives
  the message, it knows whether it's a light
  sensor, temperature sensor, sound sensor, etc.

- The `Message` class allows us to send structured
  sensor data messages that contain the
  sensor values as well as the field names.

- `Message msg(transceiver)` constructs a new
  `Message` object
  that we will use to transmit the sensor data.
  We pass the `transceiver` object to the `Message`
  object so that it knows how to transmit the data.

- We call `msg.addField(...)` 3 times to
  transmit 3 field names and values:

  1. `msg.addField("ctr", counter)` sends the
    `counter` value with the field name `ctr`.
    All field names must have 3 letters/digits
    and in lowercase.  `counter` is the number
    of messages sent so far.  By sending the
    message counter, we can track at the
    IoT Gateway if any messages were lost.

  2. `msg.addField("lig", light_level)` sends
    the light sensor value as field name
    `lig`

  3. `msg.addField("tmp", temperature)` sends
    the module temperature value as field
    name `tmp`

- This occupies exactly 12 bytes, because
  4 bytes is used to encode and compress
  each field name and field value.

- A structured message may contain at most 
  3 fields.

name: ðŸ†•  - Send sensor data message
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L97-L103

- `msg.send()` sends the message via the
  `transceiver` / `UnaShieldV1` object

- This function returns true when sent
  successfully, false otherwise (e.g. module failure)

- When the function returns true, we increment
  the count of successful messages:

  `successCount++`
  
- Else we increment the count of unsuccessful messages.

  `failCount++`
  
- Regardless of success or failure, we always
  increment the message counter:

  `counter++`
  
- To find out how the message is received
  by our server and recorded into a Google
  Sheet, you may read this:

  https://github.com/UnaBiz/sigfox-gcloud/blob/master/README.md

  We shall be using AWS IoT instead of Google Cloud,
  but the concepts and flows are similar.

name: ðŸ†•  - Show updates
info:
- Click here: 
  https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino#L105-L109

- In this final step we show how many
  messages were sent successfully and how
  many failed to send

- `%` is the remainder / modulus operator.
  When we write `counter % 10` we are 
  computing the remainder of `counter`
  divided by 10.

- `counter` is incremented every time we send
  a message, success or fail.  If you think about
  it, `counter % 10` equals zero after every
  10 messages.  Hence the status is shown once
  every 10 messages.
